skill.name: crafting-effective-readmes
skill.description: Use when writing or improving README files. Not all READMEs are the same ‚Äî provides templates and guidance matched to your audience and project type.
skill.summary: Create professional README documentation using audience-specific templates and proven documentation patterns.
skill.author: softaworks

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill. Static findings are false positives: markdown code formatting (backticks), reference URLs in documentation, and template placeholders. No executable code, network calls, or credential access. Safe for publication.

content.value_statement: Many projects suffer from unclear or incomplete documentation that frustrates users and contributors. This skill provides curated templates, style guides, and reference materials matched to your project type and audience.
actual_capabilities: Select appropriate README templates based on project type (OSS, internal, personal)
Apply style guide best practices for clear technical writing
Structure documentation with required sections (installation, usage, contributing)
Incorporate references from industry-standard documentation guides
Format code examples and command snippets for readability
limitations: Does not generate code or implementation details
Does not access external documentation or APIs
Does not validate existing project structure or files
Does not enforce documentation updates in repositories

use_cases.title: New open source project launch
use_cases.description: Create a comprehensive README for a public repository that includes installation instructions, contribution guidelines, and example usage.

use_cases.title: Internal team documentation
use_cases.description: Generate workplace-appropriate documentation for proprietary tools with security notes, deployment steps, and internal resource links.

use_cases.title: Legacy project improvement
use_cases.description: Review and enhance existing README files with missing sections, clearer instructions, and better organization.

prompt_templates.title: Basic README request
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the crafting-effective-readmes skill to create a README for my [language/framework] project. The project [brief description of what it does]. Target audience is [developers/end users/both].
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new project and need initial documentation

prompt_templates.title: Open source README
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the crafting-effective-readmes skill to write an open source README for my project. Include sections for installation, usage examples, testing, contributing guidelines, and license. The project is at [GitHub URL].
prompt_templates.scenario: Preparing a public repository for open source release

prompt_templates.title: Internal tool documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the crafting-effective-readmes skill to create an internal team README. Focus on deployment steps, environment variables, and security considerations. Mark sections as [internal only] where appropriate.
prompt_templates.scenario: Documenting proprietary tools for team use

prompt_templates.title: Improve existing README
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the crafting-effective-readmes skill to review and improve my current README at [file path or content]. Suggest better structure, clearer language, and add any missing essential sections based on project type.
prompt_templates.scenario: Enhancing documentation for an existing project

output_examples.input: Create a README for my Python CLI tool that processes CSV files.
output_examples.output: A complete README template including: project title, one-line description, installation via pip, usage examples with command syntax, configuration options, and a brief troubleshooting section.

output_examples.input: Write an open source README for my JavaScript library.
output_examples.output: A comprehensive documentation template with: badges, feature list, quick start guide, API reference structure, contributing guidelines, code of conduct, and appropriate license section.

best_practices: Match template selection to audience: OSS projects need contribution guidelines, internal projects need security notes, personal projects can be more casual
Include concrete code examples showing common use cases rather than generic placeholders
Organize sections by reader priority: installation and quick start first, deep reference material last
anti_patterns: Using generic placeholder text like 'Add your description here' instead of specific guidance
Including installation steps that are outdated or untested
Omitting the target audience, which leaves readers unsure if the project is for them

faq.question: What templates are available in this skill?
faq.answer: The skill includes templates for open source projects, internal team tools, personal projects, and XDG config documentation. Each template has appropriate sections for its audience.

faq.question: Can I use this skill for non-code documentation?
faq.answer: Yes. While designed for software projects, the templates work for any project needing clear documentation including installation steps, usage examples, and contribution guidelines.

faq.question: Does this skill generate code examples?
faq.answer: No. The skill provides documentation structure and guidance. You provide the actual code examples based on your project implementation.

faq.question: How do I choose the right template?
faq.answer: Consider your audience: public OSS projects need full contribution guides, internal tools need security notes, personal projects can be minimal, and config files need environment-specific setup.

faq.question: Can I customize the templates?
faq.answer: Yes. The templates are starting points. Add, remove, or modify sections based on your project needs. The skill provides guidance on what sections are essential versus optional.

faq.question: Does this skill work with any programming language?
faq.answer: Yes. The documentation templates are language-agnostic. Only the code examples you provide are language-specific.
